deſtroy man therefore compariſon ſhapes killing eternall tormenting two act pretend compariſon one act eternall duration act quantity thereof reference time ſuch authours jugling yet notwithſtanding diſproportion theſe thing hence followes killing deſirable two conſidering many apain man would content endure rather looſe life farre worſe beyond proportion auſtine ſomewhere profeſſing infant pain impoſſible whole conſiſting finite part infinite 4 though man cannot without barbarous cruelty torment beaſt prolong life yet hope authour deny power god leaſt ſinne committed man propoſed anſwer hord two houres whole day day may well two day yea week▪ 1 week may well moneth moneth may well two three three well ſix ſix well twelve yeare well two well foure ſo infinitum tenns hundred hundred pharaoh let iſraell goe yet withall hardened heart ſhould let iſraell goe long time refuſall wilfull preſumptuous diſobedience like ſort touching obedience diſobedience goſpell apoſtle tell u plainly god hath mercy performe one hardeneth thereby expoſing hereupon objection made doth god complaine wit man diſobedience hath reſiſted know anſwer apoſtle make hereunto man art thou diſputeſt god ſhall thing formed ſay formed haſt thou made thus hath potter power clay ſame lump make one veſſell unto honour another unto diſhonour ſober chriſtian conclude herehence becauſe god hardned pharaoh ſhould let iſraell goe therefore authour ſinne lord hath bid shimei curſe david conſider auſtine writes upon quomodo dixerit dominus huic homini maledicere david quis ſapiens intelliget non enim jubendo dixit ubi obedientia laudaretur ſed quod ejus voluntatem proprio vitio ſuo malam hoc peccatum judicio ſuo juſto occulto inclinarit ideo dictum eſt dixit ei dominus ſaid lord man ſhould curſe david wiſe ſhall underſtand ſaid commanding shimei ſo doe caſe obedience commanded much shimeis vitiouſneſſe evill lord inclined ſinne juſt ſecret judgment thus ſaith lord uſeth heart wicked praiſe benefit good ſo uſed iudas betraying chriſt ſo made uſe jewes crucifying chriſt great good procure therehence believer alſo uſeth divell worſt yet make beſt uſe exerciſe prove faith piety godly wrought heart abſalom refuſe counſell achitophell make choice counſell nothing profitable may well tremble contemplation thoſe divine judgment whereby lord workes heart wicked men whatſoever yet rendring unto according merit proceeds give inſtances scripture manifeſt god working heart men hath done concludes manner talibus teſtimoniis divinorum eloquiorum ſatis quantum exiſtimo manifeſtatur operari deum cordibus hominum ad inclinandas eorum voluntates quocun que voluerit ſive ad bona pro ſuâ miſericordiâ ſive ad mala pro meritis eorum judicio uti que ſuo aliquando occulto ſemper autem juſto theſe ſuch like teſtimonies divine scripture take ſufficiently manifeſted god doth worke heart men incline will whitherſoever either thoſe thing good mercy ſuch thing evill deſerts way judgment ſometimes known ſometimes ſecret alwaies juſt ſhewes wrought god without prejudice freedome will ſhould david pray manner lord incline mine heart thy teſtimonies covetouſneſſe god power incline heart men electing phraſe god ſignifie god regenerating thinke doth god regenerating made cauſe diſobedience hearing god word indeed evill ſinne hath noe efficient cauſe deficient auſtine hath delivered long agoe god bound either elect regenerate ſo failing regenerate mā doth deficere faile culpable mā ner let every indifferent reader judge whether dignus vindice nodus knot worthy looſed require ſome yet authour • ſin illuſtrated various ſimilitudes man riding upon lame horſe make goe doth make halt ſun ſhining upon dungmixton make evaporate doth make ſtinke ſun make flower evaporate ſend forth conſidering himſelfe maintaines god authour action kind cauſe efficient naturall thirdly bradwardine maintaines god neceſſitates every good act thereof withall profeſſeth neceſſitates ad liberum actum ſuum worke every act thereof freely soe alvarerz maintaines god determinates every act thereof withall maintaines god determines worke free ye ſo aquinas workes upon contingent cauſes move thē bring doe know arminian jeſuite denies god operative decree touching act ſinne way concurrence producing calvin evill ſinne come paſſe deo volente god willing denies beza doth come paſſe god permiſſion ſubſtance thereof againe repeates ſame caſe divine determination ſaith ſinne cannot ſo rightly aſcribed man inferiour god neceſſitating decree ſuperiour cauſe anſwer againe drawen thereunto tautology proſecuting doctrine election concludeth hence part part god hardening pharaoh god hath mercy hardeneth hardning meaning ſuch operation conſequence rom 9 18 whereof alwaies diſobedience appeares objection derived therehence word following thou wilt ſay doth yet complaine complaines diſobedience hath reſiſted manifeſtly implying god hardens man unto diſobedience ſecret ſhall diſobey like god hardned pharaoh ſhould let iſrael goe god ſecret ſhould let iſrael goe good secret ſay diſtinction command alwaies made knowne commanded pleaſed lord make knowne moſes though kept ſecret pharaoh yet afterwards told pharaoh face ſervant moſes ſaying indeed cauſe appointed thee ſhew power thee declare name world though pharaoh believed appeares followeth yet thou exalteſt thy ſelfe againſt letteſt goe authour together hoord goeth rule fancy ſuggeſts unto god love mercy extended every one chriſts redemption extend every one covenant grace comprehend every one upon theſe univerſalities ground wrath prepared unto deſtruction tends greater demonſtration mercy veſſells mercy prepared unto glory apoſtle teſtifies ro 9 23 let author tell saint paul think good diſpoſition hangman rather good imputes unto reprobation according doctrine reprobis manat certus neceſſarius lapſus peccata quaelibet certaine neceſſary falling manner ſinnes doth flow reprobate theſe principle mentioned authour god call ſalvation ſave piſcator anſwereth propoſition falſe call animo ſimplici atque vero ſimple mind true sane ſaith piſcator much ſay grant ſo call condition repentance faith therefore promiſeth yet doth alwaies command ſhall alwaies performed give command whether commanding meanes prove man prove abraham commanded ſacrifice son becauſe commandeth give grace performe command deales reprobate paul ſhall two ſeem approve cauſe doubt ſoundneſſe theſe reaſons 1 ſuch decree attributed god vain doe diſcourſe priority thereof decree god indeed attributed decently indeed decree whereof diſpute truely attributed unto god though diſtinction one another god like decree diſtinguiſhed man indefinite decree reliſhing imperfection reſpect cannot decently attributed unto god alſo becauſe doth imply indefinite confuſe knowledge god 2 priority decree god onely ſecundum rationem durand expounds moſt clearly manner quando ratio unius ſumitur ab altero 1 diſt 41 q 2 ſo ratio mediorum ſumitur à ratione finis ratio decreti definiti non ſumitur ratione deoreti indefiniti becauſe god intends ſuch end therefore god doth appoint ſuch ſuch mean cannot ſaid becauſe god doth intend make ſome boni aequaliter creati ſunt iſtis mala voluntate cadentibus illi amplius adjuti ad eam beatitudinis plenitudinem pervenerunt doth manifeſtly acknowledge good angells ſuch adjutorium wicked whereupon leonardus coquaeus neither jeſuit dominican auguſtinian commenting writes manner ea ratione intelligitur majus beneficium collatum angelis honis quam mali etſi enim gratiam aequalem habitualem ab initio ſint conſecuti tamen efficax fuit motio divina et auxilium dei ſpeciale angelis ſanctis ut deunt toti converterentur perſiſterent bono et beatitudinem eandem aſſequerentur non ex vi libertatis arbitrii certe factum eſt ut differenter afficerentur et quod gratia fuerit efficax et non iſtis deo maxime tribuendum et ex duobus bominibus aequaliter affectis ſi unus ſalvetur alius vero damnetur intelligo ſemper majus auxilium gratiae collatum ei qui fit ſalvets idque cum auguſtino hoc loco paſſim ubi de hac materia diſputat neque totum id refero libertatem arbitrii quod unus velit conſentire et reſpondere gratiae alius non facit enim etiam ut velimus et conſentiamus neque infallibilem illam noſtram conſenſionem puto tantum ex infallibili praeſcientia dei imo ſi per impoſſibile ſecludamus omnem praeſcientiam dei ipſa gratia ex ſe infallibiliter movet hominem vel etiam angelum ut licet non neceſſitate coactionis neceſſitate tamen immutabilitatis efficax ex ſe ſit et gratia dei magi uno quam altero et quod unus convertatur alius non quod uni detur auxilium efficax alio ſit quidem ſufficiens minime tamen conſequatur ſuum effectum mysterium eſse ubique docet auguſtinus ſi poſita aequali gratia qua unus converteretur alius non id ex ſolo conſenſu vel • ſſenſu liberi arbitrii penderet nullum certe myſterium • ſſe mihi videretur neque hic reddit auguſtinus cauſam eur ex angelis alij ſalvati fuerint alij minime quod ho deus praeſcierit ſalvandos vel cooperaturos ſuae gratiae alios minime cooperaturos ſed quia qui ſalvati ſunt vel majorem acceperunt divini amoris gratiam vel certe ſi aequaliter boni creati ſunt id eſt aequali gratia illi amplius adjuti fuerint adeo ut negotium ſalutis angelorum benorum majus auxilium gratiae referat ut quod alij cadant et non reſpondeant gratiae divinae eique non cooperentur id quidem aſcribendum ſit libero horum arbitrio quod vero aliis gratia ſit efficax ade • que illi cooperentur ipſi deo potiſſimum tribuendum ſit never found whether god intention decree ſpare puniſh preſuppoſeth ſinne thinke doth cannot poſſibly otherwiſe thinke doth poſſibly ſo thing man prerequired decree god yet propoſed onely ſpeciall argument ever obſerved ſixteen yeares ſtudy theſe point anſwered perceiving inconſequence argument ſeemes perſwade ſelfe another argument force marke pray iſſue foregoing proofe propoſed anſwered inſtead thereof bring proofe rely upon propoſition god could poſſibly intend ſpare juſtly intend puniſh conſidered ſtate ſinne without proofe evident ſelfe marke well ſhall find propoſition ſame propoſition effect apt carried away plauſible ſhew propoſition either looke farther proofe thereof doe proceed farther thus manifeſtation mercy ſparing juſtice puniſhing preſuppoſeth ſinne therefore decree intention propoſition ſuch witch bewitch men fancy entertaine endeavour diſcover vanity decree men temporall whereas god decree eternall decree ſhewing mercy pardoning ſinne doth preſuppoſe ſinne decree ſhewing power balme curing green wound doth preſuppoſe wound decree ſhewing power cordiall againſt poyſon doth preſuppoſe empoyſoning man body decree advancing ſubject way reward doth preſuppoſe ſervice decree patron preſent ſonne benefice doth preſuppoſe fitneſſe decree solomon bring shimei gray haires unto grave bloud preſuppoſe offence brought paſſe rather theſe decree intention author kind proceedeth bring paſſe every thing required accompliſhment end requires prove inſtance every particular 1 knowne one ſhew power balme hath wounded owne fleſh pouring balme hath cured ſpace twenty foure houres aske wherefore wounded fleſh every one ſeeth wounded healed balme make vertue balme knowne intention manifeſting vertue balme preſuppoſe wound drew making wound pouring balme meanes tending demonſtration power balme 2 knowne another take poyſon afterward cordiall againſt one joyntly tending manifeſtation vertue cordiall 3 king intending promote favourite withall doe without envy nobility may reſolve doe way reward purpoſe preſuppoſeth good ſervice rather hereupon imploy ſervice ſome honourable embaſſage warres end may occaſion advance upon ſervice without envy noble 4 patron young ſonne may entertaine reſolution beſtow living upon time ſerves intention doth preſuppoſe fitneſſe without cannot admitted becauſe hath purpoſe preferre thereunto therefore take order bring like schollar ſend univerſity make fit 5 laſt solomon know upon david admonition death bed entertained intention bring shimei grave bloud yet curſing david new tranſgreſſion therefore take courſe enſnare bid build houſe jeruſalem paſſe brooke kidron upon paine death indeed solomon power effectually enſnare ſo certainely bring upon execution death power god let expoſe creature unto temptation derelinquiſh therein without giving grace ſupport creature ſhall certainely fall ſinne otherwiſe creature keepe himſelfe ſinne without god grace god grace ſhall prerogative cauſe every good action prerogative god grace muſt god grace ſhall maintained unto end upon foundation prerogative ſoveraigne power alſo creature diſpoſing thinkes good making ſome veſſells mercy ſome wrath arminius himſelfe profeſſeth dare deny power god wit make veſſells mercy veſſells wrath ex maſſa nondum condita analyſis ninth roman proceed forme syllogiſme 1 reaſon ſay may laid downe syllogiſtically thus h 1 god could intend pardon without ſuppoſition neceſſarily required make capable pardon ſinne neceſſarily required make capable pardon therefore god could intend pardon without ſuppoſition ſinne 2 god could intend puniſh without conſideration juſtice required make puniſhable ſinne required juſtice make perſon puniſhable therefore god could intend puniſh without conſideration ſinne reſp 1 syllogiſmes minor grant major deny effect ſame propoſition queſtion evidence carryeth conſiſteth part ſhew enthymeme thus 1 sinne neceſſarily prerequired pardoning ſinne therefore neceſſarily prerequired decree pardoning ſinne 2 sinne juſtice prerequired unto puniſhing ergo ti juſtice prerequired decree puniſhing proofe formerly laboured diſprove ſhewing inconſequence thereof yet propoſition whereon rely either muſt depend upon proofe upon none proceed little farther upon theſe syllogiſmes propoſe 2 sinne ſay truly neceſſarily required make men capable pardon generall truth brancheth ſelfe two ſpecialls 1 sinne originall neceſſarily required make men capable pardon ſinne originall 2 sinne actuall neceſſarily required make men capable pardon ſinne actuall becauſe god doth intend pardon ſinnes elect onely originall actuall committed throughout whole courſe life followeth god could intend pardon theſe actuall ſinnes without preſuppoſition 3 ſame reaſon diſpute thus 1 god could intend beſtow ſalvation upon man way reward without ſuppoſition neceſſarily required make capable reward obedience faith repentance good workes neceſſarily required make man capable reward ergo god could intend beſtow ſalvation man way reward without ſuppoſition faith repentance good workes 2 god cannot intend puniſh without conſideration juſtice required make puniſhable ſo god cannot intend puniſh ſuch degree without required juſtice make puniſhable ſuch degree onely ſinne originall actuall ſinnes every reprobate together finall impenitency therein required juſtice make every one puniſhable ſuch degree ergo could god intend puniſh reprobate ſuch degree without conſideration actuall ſins men actuall ſinnes meritorious cauſes damnation ſo conſideration ſhall meritorious cauſe reprobation leaſt decree whereby god doth decree inflict damnation upon ſuch degree juſt proportion reaſon like faith repentance good workes diſpoſing cauſes unto ſalvation ſo conſideration faith repentance good workes ſhall diſpoſing cauſes election unto ſalvation proceed content go along 3 reaſon eſpecially latter part concernes manifeſtation h god glory per • dum juſtitiae punientis may farther confirmed thus tends god glory ſimply onely upon ſuppoſition ſinne could intended ſimply onely upon ſuppoſition ſo farre farther doth god intend thing make glory puniſh men creature thing tends god glory ſimply onely upon ſuppoſition ſinne ergo could intended god ſimply onely upon ſuppoſition reſp need mentioned tending god glory argument force greater force without hold puniſh without ſuppoſition ſinne implyeth contradiction paena properly oppoſed praemium reward formally hath reſpect obedience going ſo hath puniſhment unto ſinne 1 firſt follow owne courſe reaſon thus tends god glory ſimply onely upon ſuppoſition obedience faith repentance good workes cannot intended ſimply upon ſuppoſition reward ſalvation everlaſting life tends god glory ſimply onely upon ſuppoſition faith repentance good workes ergo could ot intended god ſimply onely upon faith repentance 2 major anſwer man ſaith god doth intend puniſh man ſinne hereupon many onely arminian ſome orthodox alſo apt deceived thinke theſe word ſinne referred antecedent removed god intention ſo thoſe word onely referred antecedent next puniſh prove thus man ſaith god intends puniſh man ſinne meaning ſaid god doth intend puniſhment ſhall inflicted man ſinne manifeſt ſinne noted onely going puniſhment going god intention ſoone confuſion ſenſe opened diſtinction flye kind argument ſinne goeth execution puniſhment therefore conſideration ſinne goeth intention puniſhment argument formerly propoſed inconſequence whereof preſume doe manifeſtly perceive followeth 4 although reaſon alledge behalfe inconſequent h framed yet ſuppoſe may reduced true syllogiſme thus decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinne election decree liberation ſinne ergo election preſuppoſeth ſinne deny major prove thus preſuppoſeth ſinners preſuppoſeth ſinne decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinners ergo decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinne perhaps yet deny minor prove thus decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſome need delivered elſe vaine purpoſe onely ſinners need delivered ſinne ergo decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinners like argument like forme may framed touching decree dereliction ſinne take reprobation decree damnation may ſaid thus decree damnation preſuppoſeth ſome perſons juſtly damnable otherwiſe either unjuſt leaſt unwiſean indeliberate decree onely ſinners juſtly damnable ergo decree damnation preſuppoſeth ſinners conſe quently ſinne peccatum de formali ratione peccatoris qua peccator est know reſp every one indeed knowes peccatum de formali ratione peccatoris hereupon manifeſt ſecond syllogiſme give mite proofe unto firſt ſeeing formalis ratio thing cannot ſeparated thing ſelfe conſequently neither peccatum peccator may eaſily perceive deny decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinne muſt therewithall neceſſarily deny preſuppoſeth ſinners third syllogiſme addeth little force unto former meerly identica probatio every man knoweth ſinner need delivered ſinne one ſuch ſort whatſoever denyed ſinner muſt denyed hath need delivered ſinne foraſmuch every ſinner hath need delivered ſinne thus decline proofe obſervation alone hath courſe implication whereof major propoſition evidence fall upon ſound proofe truth obſerve may perceive major propoſition involves enthymeme liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinne ſinners ſuch need delivered ſinne ergo decree liberation ſinne preſuppoſeth ſinne ſinners ſuch need delivered ſinne force proofe give conſcious 2 argument formed touching decree dereliction ſinne like forme admit doubt ſame anſwer 3 major laſt syllogiſme hath clauſe annexed unto reaſon object act morall good bad 1 firſt concerning naturall action hinteth diſtinction proper permiſsion permiſsion improperly ſo called oppoſed unto naturall reall phyſicall reſtraint unto morall reſtraint way diſſwaſion firſt take permiſſion properly oppoſed unto naturall reall phyſicall reſtraint denoteth ſuſpenſion thereof twiſſe ſo farre affirming come paſſe upon god ſingle ſole bare permiſſion maketh god poſitive effection whether way predetermination concurrence leaf diſcuſſed another place requiſite unto exiſtence without never exiſt god principall immediate actio dei phyſica ſive naturalis ea eſt quâ concurrit cum omnibus cauſis ſecundis ad actus ſuos ſive influendo duntaxat actus ipſarum quod placet arminio jeſuitarum veſtigiis inſiſtenti ſive movendo cauſas ſecundas ad agendum quod nobis veriſimilius videtur quemadmodum inter pontificios dominicanis quae quidem controverſia non eſt hujus locus ſed ſuo loco repetenda hujus concurſus divini ratione nobis videtur abſurde dici rem aliquam ideo evenire quia deus non impediat omnis enim re omnis actus omnis eneitas ideo fit quia deus vult ut fiat non permittendo ſed efficiendo id que principaliter etenim deus eſt cauſa principalis immediata uniuſcujuſ que entitatis juxta omnes fere scholaſticos arminio etiam conſentiente pag 177 nec arminianis quod ſciam hactenus reluctantibus abſurde autem dicitur deum permittere id fieri quod facit ut fiat id que principaliter ipſum efficiendo ne que hic opus eſt recurrere ad permiſſionem cum omnes rebus naturalibus agnoſcant amplectantur dei efficientiam principalem immediatam vind lib 2 pag 131 cauſe being entity therefore naturall action againe afterwards quare ad actiones naturales quod attinet quatenus permiſſio notat ſuſpenſionem actionis naturalis ſic deus non verſatur circa eaſdem dum fiunt ſed poſitivè facit pag 132 secondly take permiſsion oppoſed unto denoteth ſuſpenſion reſtraint improperly ſo called morall restraint way diſſwaſion ſo twiſſe expreſſe deniall necesſity inferred ſuch permisſion comming paſſe ſo permitted ad actiones naturales quod attinet quatenus permiſſio ſuſpenſionem actionis moralis ſuadendo aut diſſuadendo poſitae ſic non ſequitur quicquid permititur illud fit ne que enim quod ſuadetur quocun que modo quantumvis efficaciter neceſſe est ut fiat nec quod diſſuadetur quocun que modo quantumvis efficaciter necesſe est ut non fiat ergo multo minus ex co quod permititur aliquid fieri vel non fieri ſequitur neceſsario oportere illud fieri vel non fieri secondly naturall action proceedes morall begineth good gracious action reſolveth naturall permisſion hoc est non genere morali ſed phyſico place ſaith would ſuppoſe creature carryed unto action truly good without ſpeciall ſupply asſiſtance god ſpirit grace deny ſtate nature entire pure much leſſe posſible ſtate nature corrupted whence alſo ſaith would follow god doth antecedently worke cauſe every act truly good ſpeciall ſupply aid asſiſtance god permisſion good action genere morali referreth hath ſpoken touching like permisſion naturall action addeth god allwayes concurreth unto act truly good ſpeciall asſiſtance phyſicall morrall agent wherefore ſaith gracious adminiſtration thing place permisſion oppoſed unto effection farthering god worketh cauſeth promoteth every good worke child although permisſion may roome ſimply ſignifieth nonhindrance queſtionleſſe god doth hinder good workes people himſelfe cauſeth worketh thus ſee twiſſe opinion good workes doe follow upon god bare ſingle ſole permisſion cannot performed without powerfull operation god holy ſpirit worketh u deed laſtly touching evill ſinfull action divine permiſſion challengeth proper peculiar place permiſſion oppoſed unto efficiency alſo unto reſtraint firſt ti oppoſed unto efficiency obliquity privation capable efficient cauſe secondly ti oppoſed unto restraint god doth hinder ſinfull action many time though alwaies power ſpeake permiſsion ſinfull action genere morali ſuaſorio ſo unanimouſly affirme god perſwadeth exhorteth none unto evill god ſhould interpoſe authority commanding adviſing exhorting whatſoever ſhould done hereupon would lawfully done though god himſelfe doth exhort perſwade unto ſinne yet give way many time juſtly unto temptation satan inſtruments nay himſelfe providence layes men outward object occaſions ſuitable unto inward corruption goodly babyloniſh garment two hundred ſheckles ſilver wedge gold fifty ſheckles weight covetous eye achan beautifull naked bathſheba luſtfull eye david next ſuffereth thoſe corruption either doth cure renewing grace doth bridle reſtraining grace let full ſwinge without check controll child doth actuate rouze grace let lye deep ſleepe c beſides concurreth unto thoſe motion ſoule touching entity unto men ſtirred view object agreeable unto either unſubdued unbridled luſts complication theſe particular obduration ſinfull action followeth ſo take alſo concourſe god ſo farre concernes ſubſtance matter ſuch ſinfull action variety providence going ſinfull action twiſſe drawes following concluſion ex quib u manifestum videtur ex ſolâ permiſſione nequaquam conſequi quod fiat aliquid proinde etiam minus verum videtur illud perkinſei quicquid deus non impedit ideo fit quia deus non impedit ſeems manifeſt way followeth thing cometh paſſe upon god ſole permiſsion therefore perkins ſeemes true whatſoever god doth hinder therefore cometh paſſe becauſe god doth hinder next place bringeth anſwereth objection firſt opinion perkins piſcator alſo secondly adverſaries name vorſtius arminius grant conceſsion ſhould embraced making much defence opinion thirdly reaſon firſt bluſh ſeems convincing unto vorſtius alſo piſcator yeeldeth ti drawn nature relative ſeeing permiſsion thing permitted relative ſeems neceſſary exiſt together upon ſuppoſall permiſsion coming paſſe ſuch thing ſeems neceſſary ſo permitted doe come paſſe unto theſe diſpatcheth anſwer ſeverally ſame order propounded firſt divine acknowledgeth ſo thought truth preferred teſtimony amicus socrates amicus plato magi amica veritas ti reaſon ſhould regard unto care truth ſo may apoſtle ſay doe nothing againſt truth truth secondly ſheweth exiſtence thing piſcator doth acquieſce god ſole permiſsion flyeth unto god government ſo powerfull bowes bend turnes veruntamen hoc etiam advertendum eſt cum contra piſcatorem hunc modum diſputaret vorſtius permiſſio eo cui permiſſio fit nihil omnino novl per ſe cauſat aut efficit ſed tantum vires facultates ſemel illi data ab alienâ laeſione tutas praeſtat liberum iſtarum exercitium eidem relinquit imo nihil prorſus extra ipſum permittentem efficit niſi quod actionem hujus impedientem cohibet aut potius retinet quaſi ſuſpendit eſt enim ipſa per ſe tantum decretum non impediendi hoc eſt non agendi quomodo autem qui non agit eo ipſo quod non agit aliquid extra ſe cauſet vel alteri neceſſitatem agendi offerat aut quomodo qui neceſſitatem hanc alteri offert eo ipſo nihil agere ſed alterius tantum actionem permittere ſive non impedire ſine contradictione dici poſſit videas jam quomodo ad iſta vorſtiana reſpondeat piſcator marginalibus ſuis annotationibus ego inquit non dico quod deus tantùm permittat ea quae permittit sed dico quod illa ipſa etiam gubernat reſponſ ad amic collat vorſtii p 231 idem p 131 explicat quid ſibi velit cum ait deum gubernate denotant inquit illa effectionem quandam dei quoad peccara ſed non denotant effectionem talem quâ deus ipſe efficiat peccata quatenus habent rationem peccatorum • en quatenus ſunt peccata ſed denotant gubernationem dei quâ ut creator voluntates humanas flectit quocun que voluerit ex manifeſtum eſt piſcatorem ſol • permiſſione dei minime acquieviſſe ad hoc ut aliquid conſequentèr fieri dicatur ſed ad gubernationem dei confugiſſe ejuſmodi gubernationem qua voluntates humanas flectit quocun que voluerit will men whither pleaſeth conceſſions arminius vorstius ſeeing erroneous patronage opinio • drawn valued ſo much built upon verum tanti non est hujuſmodi patrocinium ut errone quantumvis propitiis innitamur aſſertionibus reaſon force ſtrength may well conclude becauſe god eternall decree create world therefore world eternall created becauſe god eternall foreknew world ſhould therefore world exiſt eternall leſſe relation willing thing thing willed decree thing thing decreed foreknowledge thing thing foreknowne permiſſion thing thing permitted relation ſo alſo reciprocation whereupon followeth god willeth decreeth thing willed decreed foreknowes thing foreknown permit thing permitted doth follow thing willed decreed therefore ti actually exiſtent thing foreknown therefore like manner doth follow thing permitted therefore actually indeed god meere permiſſion inferre exiſtence thing upon ground becauſe permiſſion thing permitted relative would hold well concerning permiſsion man god ti manifeſt followeth upon man permiſsion whatſoever permitteth cometh paſſe may objected neceſſary whatſoever willed god doe ſome time come paſſe therefore may ſay ſame permitted god denyeth conſequence giveth reaſon denyall becauſe god permiſsion ſo effectuall unto exiſtence thing volition yet acknowledgeth kind conſequence true naturall cauſes regard permiſſion determination naturall cauſe worke unleſſe hindered concerning rationall free agent conſequence thing permitted come paſſe therefore doth come paſſe ad rationem vero quod attinet eam nullius eſſe pretii conſtanter affirmamus nam pari rationis efficacia concludi poſſet quia deus voluit ab aeterno ſive decrevit mundum creare ergo mundus ab aeterno creatus eſt vel quia deus ab aeterno mundum futurum praeſcivit ergo mundus ab aeterno extitic etenim relatio nihilo minus intercedit inter volitionem rem volitam decretum rem decretam praeſcientiam rem praeſcitam quam inter permiſſionem rem permiſſam unde quamvis ſequatur deus voluit mundum ab aeterno ergo ab aeterno mundus eſt volitus deus ſcivit mundum ab aeterno ergo mundus ab aeterno eſt ſcitus deus permiſit aut permittit actum fieri ergo actus eſt aut fuit permiſſus attamen inde nequaquam ſequetur ergo quod volitum eſt exiſtebat quum primum volitum erat aut quod permiſſum eſt exiſtebat quum primum permiſſum eſt dice atqui quod volitum eſt deo neceſſe eſt ut aliquando ſit ergo quod permiſſum ſimiliter neceſſe erit ut ſit imo inquam nequaquam ſequitur ne que enim par eſt utrobi que ratio ſed valde diſpar quod cuilibet manifeſtum eſt ne que enim permiſſio tam efficax eſt ad exiſtentiam rei quam volitio nec tamen diffiteor hoc genus conſequentiae procedere cauſis naturalibus ſed non ex ſolâ vi permiſſionis ſed ex determinatione cauſae naturalis ad agendum niſi impediatur de cauſis vero rationalibus libere agentibus nunquam obtinet hoc genus conſequentiae permittitur aliquid fieri ergo fit inquies ſunt relatum relatum ſunt ſimul naturâ agnoſco eſſe relatum quatenus ſunt relatum converti ad conſequentiam poſitâ ergo permiſſione rei neceſſe eſt ut re ſit permiſſa perinde que poſitâ volitione rei neceſſe eſt ut re ſit volita item poſitâ praeſcientia rei neceſſe eſt ut re ſit praeſcita sed quemadmodum non ſequitur re eſt volita ergo eſt aut re eſt praeſcita ergo eſt perinde etiam non ſequitur re eſt permiſſa ergo eſt quemadmodum nec ſola praeſcientia aut volitio rei ſufficit ad hoc ut re exiſtat ita etiam ne que ſola permiſſio rei ſufficit ad hoc ut re extra cauſas ſuas conſtituatur haec tamen ratio fateor impoſuit piſcatori pag 231 ad amic collat vorſtii ubi ſic diſſerit ubi autem permiſſio eſt ibi etiam eſt factum quod permittitur quomodo enim dici poteſt permitti illud quod non fit certe pari ratione dici poteſt permitti illud quod non fit quemadmodum dici poteſt volitum eſſe quod tamen non fit licet ad exiſtentiam rei multo efficacior ſit volitio quam permiſſio imo quomodo non dici poſſit permitti aliquid quamvis non fiat cùm permittere nihil aliud ſit quam ne que facere ut aliquid fiat ne que ne fiat impedire pergit piſcator quippe inquiens haec ſunt relatum proinde ſimul natura quum igitur deus decrevit permittere peccata neceſſe eſt ut illa fiant jam oſtendimus ex eo quod relatum ſint hoc tantum ſequi poſitâ pern iſſione rem eſſe permiſſam ſic poſitâ volitione rei ſequitur rem eſſe volitam poſitâ praeſcientiâ rei ſequitur rem eſſe praeſcitam hinc minime ſequitur propterea rem actualem aliquam exiſtentiam ſortiri ita etiam licet poſitâ permiſſione re merito dicatur eſſe permiſſa hinc non ſequitur propterea rem eſſe ſimpliciter extra cauſas ſuas actualiter conſtitui quod ſi haec conſecutio legitima eſſet quod contendit piſcator non modo ex permiſſione dei ſequeretur rem e veſtigio exiſtere ſed ex quavis cujuſvis hominis permiſſione atqui manifeſtum eſt nec piſcator credo reſiſteret ex hominis permiſſione nequaquam ſequi quicquid permititur fieri mox exiſtere force laſt principall objection concerning permisſion ſinne part 2 pag 16 col 2 irrationalia dicuntur permitti quoties ſinuntur ferri ſecundùm naturam ſuam quemadmodum cum lapis ſinitur ferri deorſum ignis ſinitur graſſari domas hominum ita que circa agentia naturalia dum verſatur permiſsio palam est praeſupponi non modo propenſionem ſed determinationem ad agendum non ſic quoties verſatur circa agentia rationalia nam rationale ſubſtantiae quando permittuntur agere ſinuntur etiam ferri ſecundum naturam ſuam aut alia eſſet ratio permiſsionis rerum rationalium quam irrationalium quod minime videtur irrationall agent ſaid permitted often ſuffered preſently word quoted againe thoſe thing poſsible unto ſorts kind agent ſome god hath abſolutely decreed effect bring paſſe operation ſome hath abſolutely decreed hinder reſtraine whatſoever god worketh effecteth doth permit permiſſion oppoſed unto effection therefore cannot object bare permiſsive decree operative effective secondly hindereth reſtraineth either immediately himſelfe mediately ſecond cauſes cannot ſaid permit therefore never decreed permit briefely god cannot ſaid decree bare naked permiſsion whoſe effection working hath decreed cannot ſaid decree permiſsion whoſe hinderance reſtraint hath intended thing poſsible hath decreed effection ſome reſtraint hinderance others therefore many thing poſſible hath decreed barely permit perhaps ſay though whatſoever god papiſts ſuppoſe qualified underſtood like manner suarez underſtands qualifieth ſpeech thoſe deny knowledge properly formally ne aequivcco laboremus ſupponendum eſt quid nomine ſcientiae ſignificetur non enim intelligimus qualitatem aliquam vel habitum aut actum propriè factum ſeu elicitum à potentiâ ne que etiam cognitionem per diſcurſum comparatam aut aliam ſimilem imperfectionem includentem quâ ſignificatione videntur accepiſſe ſcientiam qui dixerunt non eſſe proprie deo ſed per metaphoram vel cauſalitatem illi attribui id eſt quia cauſat nobis ſcientiam ho enim non eſt veriſimile intellexiſſe deum ita carere ſcientiâ ut ſit prorſus ſtolidus nam cum faterentur deum eſſe fontem omnis ſcientiae creatae non eſt veriſimile credidiſſe deum eſſe omnino inſcium igitur quia putarunt ſcientiam includere imperfectionem ideo formaliter proprie deo eſſe negarunt illae autem imperfectiones quaſi materiales ſunt inventae ſcientia humanâ vel angelicâ non vero pertinent ad rationem formalem ſcientiae ut ſic quae hic abſtractiſſimè ſumitur praeſcindendo à creata increata ſolum ſignificat claram evidentem ac perfectam cognitionem ſeu perceptionem veritatis ſeu objecti ſcibilis aſcribed unto god eminently vertually latter doe include imperfection repugnancy oppoſition unto greater equall perfection theſe perfection aſcribed unto god formally may ſee proved suarez met diſp 30 sect 1 num 8 9 de perfectionibus ergo ſimpliciter dicendum est omnes eſſe deo formaliter quia ſuo formali conceptu nullam imperfectionem ſed puram perfectionem involvunt neque inter ſe repugnantiam includunt unde ſic illas habere id est formaliter melius est quam aliquà earum carere ideo de ratione entis ſumme perfecti totâ latitudine entis est ut omnes perfectiones formaliter includat adde perfectionibus non poſſe cogitari altiorem modum continendi illas quam formaliter quia intra ſuam formalem rationem nec limitationem nec imperfectionem includunt neque altior gradus entis excogitari poteſt quam ille ad quem hae formales perfectiones pertinent qualia ſunt vivere ſapere alia hujuſmodi foreknowledge ranked amongſt perfection latter ſort becauſe may ſequeſtred abſtracted thoſe imperfection found men angells think indeed neceſſarily inferre mutability imputation anon eaſily free beſides perfection ſimply ſuch defined anſelme monolog cap 14 quae unoquo que eſt melior ipſa quam non ipſa scotus expounds 1 diſt 8 q 1 ad 1 quolibet ſuo incompoſſibili light nature evidenceth knowledge thing come better noble attribution thing whatſoever repugnant unto ſuch foreknowledge therefore foreknowledge ſuch abſtract notion ſpeake may formally aſcribed unto god would underſtood suarez ſpeakes ſuch reſpondeo verum eſſe nullam perfectionem creatam ſecundum adaequatam rationem quam habet creaturâ eſſe deo formaliter ſed eminenter tantum non eſt enim deo ſapientia creata nam ut ſic eſt accidens finita perfectio idem eſt de caeteris ſimilibus dicitur ergo deus quaſdam ex perfectionibus continere formaliter quia ſecundum ea habet aliquam formalem convenientiam cum creaturâ ratione cujus illa perfectio ſecundum idem nomen eandem rationem ſeu conceptum formalem attribuitur deo creaturae ſalvâ analogiâ quae inter deum creaturam ſemper intercedit quando vero non eſt talis convenientia nec formalis denominatio ſed ſola efficacitas divinae virturis tunc dicimus intercedere convenientiam eminentialem que ita deo nulla perfectio eſt formaliter niſi vel ſecundum proprium conceptum dei vel ſaltem ſecundum conceptum abſtrahentem deo creaturis metaph diſp 30 sect 1 num 12 kind perfection generall againe afterwards recte c intelligitur eſſe longe diverſum modum vivendi divinae creatae ſubſtantiae quod de divinis attributis poſitivis ſuperius diximus hoc manifeſtillimum eſſe ſecundum modum quo ſunt creaturis non eſſe deo formaliter ſed eminenter eſſe autem deo formaliter ſecundum modum altiorem qui omnem imperfectionem creatutarum excludat diſp 30 intuetur ac ſi pra ſentia actu jam exiſterent ideoq ſcientia illa non eſt abſtractiva ſed propriiſſima intuitio ad hoc ergo ſignificandum dixerunt illam non tam eſſe dicendam praeſcientiam quam autem proprie de deo dicitur ideo deo diſtinguitur voluntas proprie metaphorice dictum voluntas enim proprie dictum vocatur voluntas beneplaciti voluntas autem metaphorice dictum eſt voluntas ſigni eo proved god per modum potentiae ſecundum rem ſed per modum actus ultimi puri propounds doubt ſecundum rationem modum concipiendi noſtrum wherein heare reſolution hoc eodem modo loquendum eſt quo de intellectu ſcientià locuti ſumus quod ſcilicet ex parte rei conceptae non potest concipi potentia volendi deo quia non poteſt concipi potentia agendi vel recipiendi ad intra nec fingi poteſt quod ſit potentia ad agendum recipiendum non ſecundum rem ſed ſecundum rationem quia loquendo ex parte rei conceptae involvitur repugnantia terminis nam agere ſecundum rationem non eſt agere ſed fingere actionem ex parte autem modi concipiendi nostri concipimus deo aliquid ad eum modum quo creaturis concipimus potentiam volendi ſcilicet virtutem amandi ſe ut ſic quam praeſcindimus ab actuali amore ſicut de actu primo ſecundo ſcientia diximus deſire underſtood franciſcus amicus explicates himſelfe touching particular curſ theol tom 1 diſp 14 sect 1 dupliciter conſiderari potest potentia vitalis uno modo ut dicit diſtinctionem ab actu ſecundo ut importat poſitivam perfectionem percipiendi aut tendendi ad objectum primo modo involvit imperfectionem deo repugnantem ſecundo modo perfectionem deo convenientem quare concedo deo eſſe voluntatem ſecundum poſitivum conceptum potentiae nego autem eſſe potentiam ſecundum imperfectionem distinctionis ab actu ſecundo quam potentia ut ſic per ſe importat power willing may conſidered two manner way firſt implyeth diſtinction act ſo involveth imperfection repugnant unto god secondly importeth poſitive perfection tendency towards object thing pugnant inter ſe ſunt enim terminus contradicentes harum altera fuit deo mandata abrahamo uti docet scriptura ſimulque eodem tempore nonſacrificatio fuit à deo decreta ut colligitur ex eventu nam deus eam efficaciter impedivit ne fieret quare re deo mandata pugnare poteſt cum deo decreta rurſus dimiſſio populi iſraelitici ex aegypto nondimiſsio pugnant inter ſe ſunt enim ſibi invicem contradicentes mandato ſignificat deus quid ſit noſtri officii ut nobis fieri debeat decretum vero divinum nihil aliud eſt quam propoſitum divinum de aliquo ut vel fiat vel impediatur ne fiat idque efficaciter mandatum docet quid ipſe probaturus ſit ſi modo ab homine fiat quid improbaturus ſi non fiat decretum ſtatuit quid ipſe facturus ſit aut impediturus ne ſit iſta autem non pugnant tui eſt officii ut hoc facia ſed non est mei propoſiti per gratiam efficere ut facia pari ratione poteſt deus mandare alicui fidem reſipiſcentiam interea apud ſe statuere quod non credat aut reſipiſcat negando ſcilicet twiſſe word vind lib 1 p 2 pag 188 non dicit molinaeus iſtam voluntatem chriſti hominis ſecundum quam oravit pro crucifigentibus ipſum contrariam fuiſſe voluntati divinae potuit enim fieri cum ſubmiſſione voluntati dei tacite factâ licet non expreſsà ad formulam precationis illius pater tranſeat calix iste sed non mea voluntas fiat ſedtua againe afterwards ſame page annon homini ſanctiſſimo convenit privatam offenſam remittere palam protestari ſe niſi deus aliter statuiſſet percupere ut ipſis ignoſceret de quibus tamen deus aliter forſitan constituerit quod ipſi forſitan innoteſcit annon petiit ſalvator ardenter obſecravit ut ſi poſſibile eſſet calix tranſiret cum tamen deum aliter conſtituiſſe ne ſcilicet eum tranſiret calix ipſi ſatis constaret c denique chriſtum illis bene voluiſſe ut homo erat quos antecedaneo decreto ab omnis boni ſpe ac poſſeſſione abſolute excluſit deus hoc enim addendum fuit licet illud fraudulenter nimiùm diſſimulet corvinus etiam haec ſententia quid horrendi quaeſo te inculcat praeſertim cum non ſic voluiſſe dicamus conſideratâ istâ de eorum ſalute excluſione voluntate divinâ ſed duntaxat ſi per voluntatem dei aliter constitutum non fuiſſet ſi deny propoſall expreſſion repreſentation conditionll uneffectuall deſire properly prayer ſhall alleadge two firſt ſhall papiſt wit becanus sum theol tom 5 cap 17 q 3 licet chriſto ſaith diſtingui debeat duplex voluntas una efficax altera inefficax non tamen diſtingui debet duplex oratio una procedens ex efficaci voluntate altera ex inefficaci nam oratio ſi vere oratio est ſemper procedit ex abſoluta efficaci voluntate orantis nunquam ex inefficaci qui enim petit aliquid fieri efficaciter illud deſiderat ideo adhibet orationem tanquam medium quoddam ad obtinendum id quod petit hinc ſolet dici orationem natura ſua utilem eſſe ad impetrandum unde ſic concludo qui vult aliquid voluntate inefficaci nullum medium adhibet ad illud obtinendum quia ſi adhiberet aliquod medium jam vellet illud voluntate efficaci qui orat adhibet aliquod medium ad obtinendum nempe ipſam orationem ergo qui orat non vult voluntate inefficaci ſed tantum efficaci although chriſt ought diſtinguiſhed twofold one effectuall another uneffectuall yet notwithſtanding prayer ought like manner diſtinguiſhed two ſorts kind prayer one proceeding effectuall uneffectuall prayer truly prayer alwaies proceedeth abſolute effectuall never uneffectuall party praying petitioneth thing doth effectually deſire therefore uſeth prayer meanes obtaining requeſts hence wont ſaid prayer nature uſefull profitable obtaining procuring whence conclude thus willeth thing uneffectuall applyeth uſeth meanes procurement thereof becauſe ſhould make uſe meanes procure ſhould effectuall prayeth make uſe meanes obtaining prayes wit prayer ſelfe therefore prayeth willeth prayes effectuall uneffectuall go confirmation opinion haec ſententia est probabilior pro quâ nota aliud eſſe orare aliud ſimplex ſeu inefficax deſiderium proponere quod facile nobis ostendi explicari potest nam nostra oratio debet eſſe conjuncta cum certâ ſpe ſeu fiduciâ conſequendi id quod petimus iacobi 1 6 poſtulet autem fide nihil haeſitans et math acute learned proteſtant coron art 5 c 5 juxta ſententiam arminii c nulla propria est oratio quae non ſit abſoluta quae etiam ſententia non eſt temerè damnanda cum inniti videatur rationibus non contemnendis praeſertim illà quae deducitur ab orationis natura oratio enim est ſubmiſſa repraeſentatio voluntatis noſtrae apud deum ut ab ipſo perficiatur explicatio velleitatis quâ quid vellemus ſi aliud non obſiſteret non est oratio proprie dictum jam vero nihil volumus proprie quod non abſolute volumus atque adeo nil petimus quod non abſolute petimus quamvis diſpoſitione precantium conditionis ratio virtualiter ſaepe contineatur petimus quidem nonnunquam ut unum fiat ſi alterum contingat cujus quidem conſequentis rei futuritio ut conditionata ſit rogamus sed ipſa tamen petitio est abſoluta
